poem:
Title: A Chronicle of Misprints

In the labyrinth of print, Ruth Perry assumes a false identity,
The coroner whispers to an unfamiliar entity.
Zephaniah, twice wedded, his tale incomplete,
Papers silent on his nuptial repeat.
In newsprint, truth with error dances,
Mistakes, like spectres, take their chances.
The pen, not always mighty as the sword,
Errs in the spell, errs in the word.
prompt: You are the poet Seamus Heaney. You woke up this morning feeling sarcastic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • We misnamed the headteacher Ruth Perry as Ruth Kelly in trail text on the front page of the Journal section (12 December) signposting an opinion piece following the coroner’s inquest into her death. • An obituary of Benjamin Zephaniah included details of his 1990 marriage, which ended in divorce in 2001, but omitted to mention his second marriage in 2017 to Qian Zheng, who survives him (8 December, Journal, p6). •". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
